p:
The relevance of optimal maternal nutrient supply in the periconception period and during pregnancy has received close attention due to growing evidence showing its impact on offspring development
1– 3 . Imbalance in the availability of uterine-derived histotroph
4 as well as placental nutrient supply, either by overfeeding or underfeeding, leads the fetus to physiological and metabolic changes with long-term consequences
5– 7 . Nutritional insults affect energy partitioning among metabolically active target tissues, such as the liver and muscle
8 , affecting economic traits such as lactation, reproduction, meat quality, body composition, and carcass weight
5, 9, 10 . These adverse long-term consequences could decrease the livestock industry’s profitability as the negative performance may be epigenetically inherited across generations
11 .
